instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light charger, white screen, fan is fast, no folder w question mark
threads.message:
I did some work surrounding the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> chip.. Now i get a white screen and the fan turns on really high and I don't get the folder with question mark - Is this a PCH issue?

My charger gives me the green light and I am getting a white screen with no folder with question mark and the fan turns on super fast.  I can't get to a screen to be able to run ASD to check sensors...

Does this sound like a PCH issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light charger, white screen, fan is fast, no folder w question mark
threads.message: Getting voltage to <CAPACITOR>C9015</CAPACITOR>? Can you do a PRAM reset?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light charger, white screen, fan is fast, no folder w question mark
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 11532"]Getting voltage to <CAPACITOR>C9015</CAPACITOR>? Can you do a PRAM reset?[/QUOTE]

Do you mean a SMC reset?  Doesn't SMC control the fans and such?  I am by no means being a jerk just trying to understand why you would suggest a PRAM reset is all..

Also you are correct there is no voltage on <CAPACITOR>C9015</CAPACITOR> and pin 2 on LCD cable looks burned out which is also on the same line.. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_LCDVDD_SW_F</SIGNAL>

Thanks for your previous prompt response!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light charger, white screen, fan is fast, no folder w question mark
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 11532"]Getting voltage to <CAPACITOR>C9015</CAPACITOR>? Can you do a PRAM reset?[/QUOTE]

I checked to see if the cap was shorted but it is not, also the pin 2 on the LCD may look like crap but it has continuity from pin 2 on LVDS connector to the cap <CAPACITOR>C9015</CAPACITOR> and to the inductor that follows beside it L9004...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light charger, white screen, fan is fast, no folder w question mark
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 11532"]Getting voltage to <CAPACITOR>C9015</CAPACITOR>? Can you do a PRAM reset?[/QUOTE]

Sorry for so many responses I should have waited and gave my results after investigating.. So I checked everything on that line and everything is good so it lead me to the <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> and it is not getting any voltage on its enable pin so nets <SIGNAL>LCD_IG_EN</SIGNAL>.   This is created by <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> PCH correct? 

So my questions are:

First What does the <SIGNAL>PP3V2_LCDVDD_SW_F</SIGNAL> do exactly?  I'm guessing it has something to do with switching something on related to LCD?  I get a white picture so isn't the LCD getting a image? 
Second What should I do at this point?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light charger, white screen, fan is fast, no folder w question mark
threads.message: Did you test the voltages on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> with the LCD plugged in? Check pin 1 with LCD plugged in, must be high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light charger, white screen, fan is fast, no folder w question mark
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 12478"]Did you test the voltages on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> with the LCD plugged in? Check pin 1 with LCD plugged in, must be high. [/QUOTE]

Indeed you where correct I did not have the LCD plugged in... The device is booting and getting to the folder with the question mark however the fan is really running fast which is making me think something is overheating.. I tried to boot up a copy of iOS through a usb drive I have and it runs super slow... I don't have a copy of ASD for this particular model.  Would you suggest I grab that?  Or any other suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light charger, white screen, fan is fast, no folder w question mark
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 12478"]Did you test the voltages on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> with the LCD plugged in? Check pin 1 with LCD plugged in, must be high. [/QUOTE]

Could it be a short under the PCH causing this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green light charger, white screen, fan is fast, no folder w question mark
threads.message: It is a sensor issue and you need to run ASD. Common fault is the trackpad sensor, is it connected? You should download the ASD torrent, google for it, it is all ASD and is 56GB or something.
